I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed 
policy-based grant to the Kingdom of Tonga for the Strengthening Public Financial Management 
Program. 
 
2.  The program is designed to support the medium-term fiscal framework and multiyear 
policy reform matrix of the Government of Tonga by supporting policies and processes for public 
financial management and private sector development.1 
  
II.  THE PROGRAM 
A.  Rationale 
3.  Tonga  faces  many  of  the  challenges  typical  of  small  island  economies,  such  as 
geographic isolation, limited human and financial resources, a small domestic market, and high 
trade  costs.  The  economy  is  narrowly  based  and  depends  on  inflows  of  remittances  and 
external assistance to support aggregate demand.  
 
4.  Since 2007, Tonga has mounted major tax policy, budget, and customs administration 
reforms,  while  strengthening  the  business  regulatory  environment  and  corporatizing  and 
privatizing  several  state-owned  enterprises  (SOEs).  But  the  country’s  geographical 
disadvantages and high level of vulnerability to climatic, political, and economic shocks have 
constrained investor potential, leading to more modest growth rates than the government had 
anticipated.  Investor  confidence  was  eroded  by  a  prolonged  civil  service  strike  and  civil 
disturbances that caused widespread damage to the capital, Nuku’alofa, in 2006. Tonga also 
suffered from a tsunami in September 2009 and cyclones in 2010 and 2012. Reconstruction 
activity  boosted  the  economy,  but  that  growth  did  not  prove  to  be  self-sustaining.  Heavy 
reconstruction  costs  have  strained  the  government’s  budget,  with  administrative  resources 
diverted from reform to reconstruction activity.2   
 
5.  Tonga has had a slow and difficult recovery from the global economic crisis. The crisis 
triggered a decline in remittances, tourism flows, and exports. Remittances as a percentage of 
gross domestic product (GDP) declined from 30% in fiscal year (FY) 2009 to 15% in FY2012, 
while tourist visitor numbers declined by 30% over the same period. Recovery continues to be 
held  back  by  ongoing  contractions  in  private  sector  credit,  weakening  agricultural  export 
performance,  and  by  the  series  of  natural  disasters  the  country  has  faced.  Government 
revenues have been hurt by the growth slowdown, and in FY2013 were 9.0% below FY2009 
receipts. Total non-grant revenue is likewise around 34% below FY2009 levels.3  
 
6.  Despite these adversities, the economy continued to expand after the global economic 
crisis—recording growth of 3.3% in FY2010 and 2.9% in FY2011—largely driven by grant and 
debt-financed stimulus as development partners and the government responded to help sustain 
aggregate demand. Capital investment and onlending from the Export–Import Bank of China 
combined to offset some of the impacts of declining revenues. However, as spending began to 
wind down, growth rates declined to 0.8% in FY2012 and 0.5% in FY2013. Private sector

development and job growth have been constrained by slow credit growth due to the weak 
economic outlook and the application of tighter lending standards by increasingly risk-averse 
banks. Grants have supported continued public spending and service delivery as tax revenue 
has declined. Budget support receipts were equivalent to 14% of revenue in FY2011, 25% in 
FY2012, and 7.0% in FY2013 (footnote 3). 
 
7.  High levels of external indebtedness make Tonga vulnerable to sudden changes in 
growth  and  revenues.  The  2013  World  Bank–International  Monetary  Fund  (IMF)  Debt 
Sustainability Analysis for Tonga assesses Tonga to be at moderate risk of debt distress, an 
improvement  over the 2012  rating (footnote  3).  Nevertheless,  official  debt repayments  are 
projected to significantly rise, from T$21 million in FY2013 to T$29 million in FY2014 and T$32 
million in FY2015, placing additional strains on the budget.4  
 
8.  Tonga’s current strategy for economic and social development is set out in the Tonga 
Strategic Development Framework (TSDF), 2011–2014.5 Public sector reform is at the forefront 
of the TSDF, which outlines strategies for (i) fostering a more efficient and effective government 
by  focusing  on  its  core  functions;  (ii)  improving  the  macroeconomic  environment  and 
strengthening fiscal management; and (iii) ensuring that public enterprises are sustainable and 
accountable and, where appropriate, moved to the private sector. 
 
1.  Government’s Policy Reform Matrix for Budget Support 
9.  In consultation with the IMF, the government developed a medium-term fiscal framework 
to steadily improve fiscal sustainability (see Table 1). Building its cash reserves to 2 months of 
operating payments and keeping external debt below its 35% of GDP target over the medium 
term are the key fiscal anchors (footnote 4). The fiscal framework was presented in the FY2014 
Budget and envisages a gradual reduction in the financing gap, after grant aid has been 
accounted for, from 3.7% of GDP in FY2013 to 2.3% of GDP in FY2016 through a combination 
of improved revenue measures and expenditure restraint.

projects) peaking in FY2014 in real terms and as a proportion of GDP. This slight increase is

driven by growth in debt servicing obligations. Restraint in salary expenditure continues with 
wage bill growth of 2.0% lower than projected inflation of 4.0%. There has been no cost of living 
adjustment to public service salaries since 2011. Wage bill growth is also lower than overall 
growth in recurrent expenditure (footnote 4). This reflects progress towards the government’s 
goal of reducing the wage bill to 45% of recurrent spending. 
11.  Change in allocations to specific government ministries are also broadly aligned with 
policy priorities. The largest proportionate reduction is in the Ministry of Infrastructure budget 
allocation (by 30%), reflecting a resumption of trend expenditure following the completion of 
large aid financed projects in the previous budget. The FY2014 allocations for the health and 
education ministries increased by 4.0% and 6.0% respectively in line with Government policy to 
reallocate expenditure to maintain social sector spending in real terms (footnote 4). 
 
12.  Ongoing dialogue between the government and development partners has resulted in 
the preparation of a multiyear joint policy reform matrix (JPRM), which outlines shared reform 
priorities that are also linked to the goals of the TSDF. The policy areas covered are public 
financial management, fiscal policy and structural reform.  For FY2014, the JPRM includes 
measures  aimed  at  strengthening  revenue  mobilization,  expanding  the  use  of  program 
budgeting, accelerating reform of SOEs and business environment reform. Partners that have 
assisted government to define reform priorities include ADB, the Government of Australia, the 
IMF, the New Zealand Aid Programme, the Pacific Financial Technical Assistance Centre and 
the World Bank. The multidonor dialogue around budget support has played a key role in 
mobilizing political attention, administrative effort and technical assistance (TA) to implement 
reforms.  
 
13.  ADB support for implementing the JPRM by strengthening public sector management 
and improving the environment for private sector development—areas of long-standing ADB 
involvement—will continue throughout the program. The program is structured around related 
outputs: (i) strengthened public financial management, (ii) strengthened fiscal policy, and (iii) 
improved implementation of structural reforms, and will be supported by ongoing ADB TA 
(funding of $675,000), which will end in December 2014.6 In 2014, although not providing 
budget support, ADB will continue to participate in formulating and monitoring the public finance 
reforms. The Government of Australia, the European Commission and the World Bank will 
continue to provide financial support to assist the government in meeting its financing gap. 
Advisors from regional TA projects,7 the World Bank and Pacific Financial Technical Assistance 
Centre will also help the government accomplish the policy actions contained in the JPRM by 
2014. 
 
14.  The program will build on lessons and outcomes of ADB’s Economic Support Program to 
Tonga,8 which was completed in June 2011. Public sector management and private sector 
development actions that were achieved under the Economic Support Program include the 
implementation of medium-term budgeting reforms, formulation and tracking of financial ratios to 
guide budget formulation, compliance with new debt management policies and procedures, 
removal  of  parliamentarians  and  civil  servants  from  SOE  boards,  and  establishment  of  a

companies registry.9 The proposed program will also draw on lessons learned by ADB, the 
World Bank, and other development partners from support for reform in Pacific island states, 
such as (i) the need for high levels of government ownership and leadership, (ii) continuity and 
careful  sequencing  of  reforms,  (iii)  the  merits  of  coordination  and  engagement  with  other 
partners, and (iv) the links between TA and program support.10 For these reasons, the program 
will be a single-tranche operation that will require all necessary policy actions need to be 
accomplished in advance of grant effectiveness. In recognition of the good progress being made 
by all development partners towards adoption of a medium term view of program and project 
assistance, ADB will adopt a programmatic approach for future budget support programs in 
Tonga. 
 
2.  Public Sector Financial Management 
15.  Performance  indicators  of  public  financial  management  in  Tonga  have  shown  an 
improvement  in  recent  years.  In  the  2007  Public  Expenditure  and  Financial  Accountability 
(PEFA) assessment, Tonga received 16 ratings of “C” or better out of 27 applicable indicators. 
In the 2010 PEFA assessment, the number of indicators where Tonga scored “C” or better 
increased to 20. However, the 2010 PEFA highlighted several weaknesses in public financial 
management. Coverage of in-year budget reports was singled out as an area for improvement 
because the existing reports could not be used to compare actual and forecast revenues and 
expenditures,  thus  weakening  control  of  budget  execution.  Links  between  budgets  and 
corporate plans were weak, and procurement suffered from insufficient oversight and poor 
regulatory compliance. 
16.  Since  2010,  the  government  has  taken  important  steps  to  improve  public  financial 
management. A medium-term fiscal framework was developed to underpin medium-term fiscal 
planning. Line ministry corporate plans were revised to focus on priority programs with clearly 
defined  performance  targets  and  resource  requirements.  Government  ministries  were 
restructured  in  2012  to  better  align  organizations  with  the  priority  functions  identified  in 
corporate programs. 
3.  Fiscal Policy 
17.  Room for fiscal maneuver is constrained by the high wage bill, public debt overhang 
(including sharply increasing debt service commitments in FY2014) and narrow revenue base. 
Since 2010, the government has taken steps to reduce tax exemptions and to broaden the tax 
base. Planned tax reforms could cause an increase in revenues by around 0.5% of GDP per 
annum in FY2014–FY2016, which is sufficient to safeguard fiscal sustainability if government 
expenditures  are  restrained  at  levels  planned  in  the  government’s  medium-term  fiscal 
framework and allowing for continued budget support assistance at similar levels to those seen 
since FY2011 (footnote 3). To help reduce the public debt, the government is strictly restricting 
all new borrowing and guarantees. 
 
18.  To  strengthen  management  of  the  wage  bill,  which  is  currently  50%  of  recurrent 
expenditure (down from 52% in FY2013), a freeze on new civil service recruitment has been in 
effect since 2010. Vacant posts have been cut back and centralized under the Ministry of 
Finance and within-year reallocation of resources to casual employment has been restricted. 
                                                
9  ADB. 2012. Completion Report: Economic Support Program in Tonga. Manila. 
10 ADB. 2011. Policy-Based Programs for the Pacific Islands. Manila.

5 
The Public Service Commission is undertaking organizational and remuneration reviews to bring 
salary  levels  into  alignment  with  ministry  core  functions  and  available  resources.  Specific 
recommendations from these reviews will be included in the JPRM for 2014 and will support 
efforts to reduce the wage bill to the government’s target of 45% of government expenditure 
(footnote 4). 
 
4.  Structural Reforms 
19.  Fostering private sector development is essential to boost growth and to help Tonga 
reduce its reliance on inflows of remittances and aid. Tonga’s tourism sector has considerable 
untapped  potential,  which  continuing  business  environment  reform  and  targeted  donor 
assistance may help unlock. Improving the efficiency of the public enterprises that provide 
infrastructure  services  could  reduce  business  costs,  as  could  further  efforts  to  reprioritize 
government  expenditure  toward  higher-priority  areas  such  as  agriculture,  fisheries,  and 
infrastructure. Development of high-speed internet capacity is also expected to create many 
new business opportunities. 
 
20.  In addition to remoteness and a small domestic market, private sector development is 
dominated by small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) whose operations are hampered by 
high business costs resulting from an onerous land registration process, weak property rights 
protection,  limited  access  to  finance,  skill  gaps,  irregular  domestic  aviation  and  shipping 
services, poorly performing SOEs, and gaps in the commercial legal framework. While modest 
levels of credit growth is forecast, continued risk aversion on behalf of commercial banks and a 
high degree of leveraging within the small private sector constrain access to credit.  
 
21.  Tonga’s portfolio of 16 public enterprises includes nine infrastructure service providers 
and seven enterprises engaged in commercial activities, with a combined asset value equivalent 
to about 40% of GDP in 2012. However, an ADB study found that in revenue terms, these SOEs 
contributed just 5.5% to GDP and had an average return on equity of 5.6% from 2002 to 2010.11 
Since 2010, portfolio performance has declined—return on equity for the 2012 reporting period 
was just 4.5%.12 The Tongan Public Enterprises Act, as amended in 2010, provides a sound 
legislative framework that supports good governance, encourages a strong commercial focus, 
and establishes strong accountabilities and transparency. Further implementation of the act, 
strict enforcement of community service obligations, divestiture of poorly performing SOEs, 
increased contracting-out, and stronger board accountability for results could contribute to more 
robust SOE performance. 
 
22.  Tonga’s efforts to reform commercial law have focused on reforming business licensing 
and encouraging investment in specific sectors. The Business License Amendment Act of 2012 
allows for licenses by businesses in perpetuity instead of licensing by activity. Further reforms 
are needed to reduce the number of ancillary licenses required by various regulatory agencies, 
and to improve the registration of business names. Changes are also required to the insolvency 
regime to improve timeliness, reduce costs, and establish clear procedures for dealing with 
firms in financial distress.

B.  Impact and Outcome 
23.  The impact of the program will be the achievement of fiscal stability as prioritized in the 
TSDF. The impact will be assessed against the achievement of the government’s target for 
external debt, which will be reported on in the government budget and in the IMF Article IV staff 
reports. The outcome will be a more sustainable fiscal position as well as improvement in 
economic management and quality of budgetary and financial management. Progress in fiscal 
stability will be tracked against progress reported in the budget, SOE financial reports, and 
Tonga’s country performance assessment scores. 
 
C.  Outputs 
24.  Strengthened public financial management. The program supports the introduction of 
program structures in the budget and the undertaking of a comprehensive review of the national 
procurement policy. Both policy actions have been accomplished. 
 
25.  The government has revised the corporate plans of the ministries and line agencies to 
better align them with the core functions of government and to clearly reflect the links between 
program goals, objectives, intended outcomes, outputs, and required resources over a 3-year 
rolling period. In 2011 and 2012, several of the ministries were restructured to better align their 
organizational  structures  with  the  program  functions  of  their  corporate  plans.  The  FY2014 
budget reflects this, and the major programs are stated in the budget document. This provides a 
basis for program budgeting and better alignment between expenditures and policy priorities. 
Aligning corporate plan priorities with budget allocation also encourages the ministries to shed 
noncore functions, and to concentrate resources on achieving agreed program targets.  
 
26.  A comprehensive review of the design and implementation of Tonga’s procurement 
policies and procedures was undertaken by a team of experts financed by the Government of 
Australia at the request of the Ministry of Finance. This review has singled out several areas 
that require strengthening, including the appointment and training of procurement officers in the 
line ministries, record-keeping and information management systems, finalizing of procurement 
regulations, and demarcation between staff recruitment and goods and services procurement. 
Follow-up measures will be mounted in 2014 and beyond. 
 
27.  Strengthened fiscal policy. The program supports the introduction of a presumptive tax 
on SMEs and an extractive industries tax. Both policy actions have been accomplished. 
 
28.  The presumptive tax on SMEs will improve collection and lower compliance costs from 
business taxes for most Tongan enterprises. It will significantly reduce the administrative burden 
on SMEs in that they will no longer need to maintain extensive records and file a complex 
company tax return. It is expected to contribute to better tax compliance and more formalization 
of small companies. The extractive industries tax creates an internationally competitive regime 
for royalties, corporate tax, and excess profit tax for companies that are currently prospecting for 
deep-sea copper deposits. This is needed to provide confidence to those who are investing, 
while ensuring a fair distribution of the returns from mining. Cabinet has approved submission to 
Parliament of both bills. 
 
29.  Improved implementation of structural reforms. The program supports the liquidation 
of Tonga Investment Limited and the sale of its Home Gas retail operations to Tonga Power 
Limited;  the  preparation  of  a  reform  and  restructuring  plan  for  Tonga  Communications 
Corporation; the preparation of a plan for private sector participation in the management of the

7 
International Dateline Hotel; steady progress in fostering good corporate governance of state 
enterprises by preparing a skills-based appointment process for SOE directors, by government 
honoring its community service obligations to the SOEs, and by around 60% of SOEs publishing 
up-to-date audited financial reports; and improvements in the commercial law framework for 
private sector development through the development of receivership legislation and a proposed 
amendment to the Registration of Business Names Act, 2002. All six policy actions have been 
accomplished. 
 
30.  The sale of the Home Gas retail operations of Tonga Investment to Tonga Power is 
designed to improve power services to consumers and to enhance Tonga Power’s ability to 
better  align  different  power  sources  with  consumer  requirements.  Liquidation  of  Tonga 
Investment will wind up what has long been a defunct enterprise. Private sector participation in 
the International Dateline Hotel is designed to upgrade facilities and restore to profitability the 
capital’s largest hotel, improving the country’s international image and encouraging tourism. 
New systems for selecting SOE directors are aimed at ensuring that those appointed to senior 
SOE management do have the requisite knowledge and skills required to effectively lead those 
firms. Ensuring that the government honors its commitment to funding its community service 
obligations rather than directing SOEs to provide uneconomical services will help improve the 
commercial orientation and performance of the state companies. Steady progress made in 
preparing and publishing SOE annual reports enhances the transparency and accountability of 
these firms. 
 
31.  Preparation of a new business name legislation is part of the process of streamlining and 
reducing the costs of business licensing. The proposed amendment to the Registration of 
Business Names Act will streamline the name registration process, reduce compliance costs, 
and provide for efficient electronic registration. The receivership bill will establish an effective 
framework  for  determining  the  respective  rights  and  liabilities  of  receivers,  creditors,  and 
grantors. It is designed to establish clear receivership procedures and to make receivership 
more attractive to liquidation in certain situations. This bill is also one of the building blocks for a 
more effective bankruptcy system, which is to be introduced in 2014. Cabinet has approved 
submission to Parliament of the proposed amendment and bill. 
 
D.  Development Financing Needs 
  
32.  The government has requested a grant not exceeding $4.5 million from ADB’s Special 
Funds resources to help finance the program. 
 
33.  ADB  is  basing  the  size  of  its  $4.5  million  grant  on  the  government’s  financing 
requirements, the cost of the government’s reform efforts and the budget support to be provided 
by other partners. The government’s financing requirements for its fiscal reform program is 
forecast to amount to $17.2 million in FY2014, $15.7 million in FY2015, and $12.9 million in 
FY2016. While this is not a cofinancing arrangement, the program will be an integral part of a 
joint undertaking with other development partners providing assistance to help meet the funding 
gap. For FY2014, the Government of Australia has agreed to provide $5.0 million, the European 
Union has agreed to provide $3.5 million, and the World Bank has agreed to provide $5.0 million 
to support implementation of the JPRM measures (footnote 4). 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
34.  Program management. The Ministry of Finance and National Planning (MFNP) will be 
the executing agency and will oversee and coordinate the timely implementation of agreed

8 
policy actions. The implementing agencies will be the MFNP; Ministry of Public Enterprises; 
Ministry of Commerce, Tourism and Labor; and Ministry of Revenue and Customs. Each will be 
responsible  for  undertaking  the  policy  actions  or  program  activities  that  fall  within  its 
responsibilities. Resources from ongoing TA will support the government in implementing the 
JPRM.  The  MFNP,  through  its  Budget  Support  Management  Committee,  will  also  be 
responsible for program administration, disbursements, and maintenance of all program records. 
ADB  and  other  development  partners  will  work  through  the  Budget  Support  Management 
Committee mechanism to monitor progress, oversee the implementation of the government’s 
reform program, and guide and direct the activities of the executing agency. 
 
35.  Implementation  period.  The  program  will  be  implemented  from  31  January  to 
31 December 2013, consistent with the government’s medium-term fiscal framework. Policy and 
operational changes agreed with the government and set out in the policy matrix were put in 
place from 31 January to 31 July 2013. 
 
36.  Procurement  and  disbursement.  The  proceeds  of  the  grant  will  be  disbursed  in 
accordance with ADB’s simplification of disbursement procedures and related requirements for 
policy-based grants.13 The proceeds will be used to finance the foreign exchange cost of items 
produced and procured in ADB member countries, excluding items included in a list of ineligible 
items  and  imports  financed  by  other  bilateral  and  multilateral  sources.14 Grant  proceeds 
disbursed against imports will require a certificate from the government stipulating that the value 
of the total imports of Tonga, minus its imports from nonmember countries, ineligible imports 
and imports financed under other official development assistance, is greater than the amount of 
the grant expected to be disbursed during a particular year. ADB will have the right to audit the 
use of the grant proceeds and to verify the accuracy of the government’s certification. 
 
37.  Tranches. The grant will be provided in a single tranche and may be withdrawn upon 
satisfaction of grant effectiveness conditions, i.e., fulfillment of all the actions in the policy matrix. 
 
38.  Counterpart funds. Local currency generated from the grant will be directed to the 
government’s bank account with the National Bank of Tonga to allow assistance toward the 
FY2014 budget. 
 
39.  Program performance monitoring and evaluation. The Budget Support Committee of 
the MFNP will establish a performance evaluation system for the program within 3 months from 
grant effectiveness and maintain this. The MFNP will monitor the program and report to ADB on 
the implementation of policy actions and their impact on budget outcomes, in line with the 
impact and outcome indicators agreed upon with the government. A review will take place at 
midterm and the government will ensure that ADB will have the opportunity to participate in this 
review. Because the impact of the program will be felt beyond the period of its implementation, 
the MFNP will continue monitoring performance until the end of 2014. The information will be 
included in the completion report.

9 
III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
40.  The program’s major benefit will be its contribution to the government’s goal of fiscal 
stability.  The  program  will  assist  the  government  in  restoring  fiscal  stability  through 
improvements in public financial management, fiscal policy, and sustained implementation of 
structural reforms to raise productivity—all features of the government’s policy reform matrix. 
These  improvements  will  help  alleviate  the  debt  overhang,  improve  the  quality  of  public 
spending, allow maintenance of the current level of health and education services, and improve 
the climate for doing business. Stronger public financial management will also improve service 
delivery, which is essential to making the growth process inclusive and to fostering employment 
and poverty reduction. 
 
A.  Economic and Financial 
41.  Improving  the  link  between  ministry  spending  and  the  overall  government  budget, 
strengthening the government’s revenue position, and reducing SOEs’ demands on the budget 
will create fiscal space and allow the government to shift expenditures to priority areas. Budget 
restraint and strengthened fiscal management will allow the government to lower its debt burden 
and reduce its vulnerability to fiscal shocks. The program’s long-term impact will be a more 
sustainable fiscal position, which implies that the government achieves its medium-term external 
debt target of 35% of GDP by FY2017 as set out in its medium-term budget framework. 
 
B.  Governance 
42.  The  government’s  ability  to  implement  its  budget  is  integral  to  the  success  of  the 
program.  The  2010  PEFA  assessment  for  Tonga  found  several  areas  of  weakness  in 
government  budgeting,  revenue  mobilization,  procurement,  and  expenditure  controls.  The 
JPRM's emphasis on improving public financial management demonstrates the government’s 
strong commitment to eliminating deficiencies and managing the budget credibly and effectively. 
 
43.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the government and the MFNP. Consistent with its commitment to good governance, 
accountability, and transparency, ADB reserves the right to investigate, directly or through its 
agents, any alleged corrupt, fraudulent, collusive, or coercive practices relating to the program. 
 
C.  Poverty and Social 
44.  Although not directly targeting the poor, stronger public financial management will have 
positive impacts on the delivery of social services, economic infrastructure, and other core 
public services. It will also contribute to macroeconomic stability, augment aggregate demand, 
and  improve  the  business  environment,  all  of  which  are  necessary  to  induce  investment, 
employment, and livelihoods needed to reduce poverty.  
 
D.  Safeguards 
45.  Program activities will be confined to policy and institutional reforms, and none of the 
activities will result in or lead to involuntary resettlement or affect indigenous peoples. No 
adverse  environmental impacts  have  been  identified.  In  compliance with  ADB’s  Safeguard 
Policy  Statement  (2009),  the  program  is  classified  under  category  C  for  impacts  on  the 
environment, involuntary resettlement, and indigenous peoples. Public consultation has been 
carried out while processing of the program and during fact finding.

10 
 
E.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
46.  The program faces three key risks: (i) political consensus needed to mount fiscal and 
SOE management reforms proves more difficult to achieve than anticipated given elections in 
2014;  (ii) staff  turnover  leaves  insufficient  qualified  and  experienced  personnel  to  manage 
implementation of program elements; and (iii) given a high degree of vulnerability to shocks, 
fiscal outcomes could diverge from what is anticipated in the budget. Major risks and mitigating 
measures are described in detail in the risk assessment and risk management plan.15 
 
47.  The program is designed to mitigate these risks. Political consensus will be obtained and 
sustained  through  government  ownership  and  leadership  of  the  JPRM  process  and  by 
continuous outreach to parliamentarians and the public, to build wider stakeholder support for 
reform. There is already a high level of media coverage and public awareness about the need 
for economic reforms and the role of development partners in supporting the government’s 
efforts through budget support and TA. To help offset the risk of skills shortages, government 
staff resources will be supplemented with ongoing TA provided by ADB and other partners. 
Quarterly monitoring of reform progress and the fiscal situation will enable the government to 
make necessary adjustments to the budget should unanticipated shocks occur. 
 
IV.  ASSURANCES 
48.  The government and the MFNP have assured ADB that implementation of the program 
will conform to all applicable ADB policies, including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail 
in the grant agreement. 
 
49.  The government and the MFNP have agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the 
program, which are set forth in the grant agreement. The grant will become effective after ADB 
is satisfied that all conditions for the release of the program tranche, as specified in the policy 
matrix and set out in Attachment 2 to Schedule 2 of the grant agreement, have been complied 
with. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
50.  I am satisfied that the proposed policy-based grant would comply with the Articles of 
Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the 
grant not exceeding $4,500,000 to the Kingdom of Tonga from ADB’s Special Funds resources 
for the Strengthening Public Financial Management Program, on terms and conditions that are 
substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft grant agreement presented to the 
Board. 
 
 
Takehiko Nakao 
President
